items.title: Here’s what Trump’s Big Beautiful Bill means for AI
Colombian gangs are using social media to recruit children, the UN warns
Cato Networks secures $359 million in latest funding round
Senate debates revised state AI regulation ban
Startups are ditching LinkedIn for TikTok to announce funding rounds
The sneaky way to to deal with public Wi-Fi restrictions
items.summary:
- You can *relay a Wi-Fi connection* from your Android phone or laptop to bypass login restrictions on devices that can't navigate captive portals, like in-flight or hotel Wi-Fi networks.
- This method saves money when device limits or extra connection fees apply, by making multiple devices appear as one to the network.
- *iPhones can't share local Wi-Fi* via hotspot, but Windows 11 and macOS support Wi-Fi sharing to distribute the connection to other devices seamlessly.

items.title: Is this Hollywood’s moment of AI reckoning?
These three underrated features make ChatGPT way better
items.author: Doug Aamoth
items.summary:
- ChatGPT offers *Edit Prompts*, allowing users to refine input in real time without losing conversation context.  
- The *Custom Instructions* feature lets users personalize ChatGPT's responses by setting tone, style, and preferences.  
- The *Regenerate Responses* option enables exploring alternative answers for better or varied outputs with a simple 'Try again' click.

items.title: Start your day right with these digital productivity tools
items.author: Jeremy Caplan
items.summary:
- The article shares a detailed morning routine powered by digital tools like the *Oura Ring* for sleep tracking, *Brain Games* for mental warm-up, and *TickTime Cube Timer* for habit-building exercises.
- It highlights productivity enhancements through apps like *Google Calendar*, *Apple Reminders*, and *Superhuman* for streamlined scheduling, task prioritizing, and email management.
- Creative and focused work is supported by tools such as *Letterly* for dictation, *Lex* for writing refinement, AI-powered image generators, and presentation apps including *Beautiful.ai* and *Keynote* to craft engaging materials.

items.title: Don’t believe these tech myths
items.summary:
- This article debunks common tech myths such as *dry rice saving wet phones*, *force-closing all apps saves battery*, and *Incognito mode fully prevents tracking*. It clarifies practical, effective alternatives.
- It explains why public USB charging ports rarely spread viruses and that VPNs are generally unnecessary on public Wi-Fi due to widespread encryption, plus what to do about privacy concerns.
- The piece also addresses the misconception that phones secretly listen to conversations, highlighting that location data and ad tracking are more likely causes of targeted ads and offering steps to reduce tracking.

items.title: These two game-changing breakthroughs advance us toward artificial general intelligence
items.summary:
- *WildFusion* technology from Duke University enhances AI robots by combining sight, touch, and sound sensors, allowing them to better perceive their environment and adapt like humans.  
- Researchers from Surrey and Hamburg universities developed a method for social robots to *self-train* by mimicking human visual focus in social situations, reducing the need for constant human supervision.  
- These breakthroughs signal a major acceleration toward *artificial general intelligence*, advancing how AI experiences and learns from the world beyond narrow task-specific capabilities.

items.title: This accuracy-obsessed weather app does one thing oh so well
items.summary:
- *Precip* is a specialized weather app focused solely on measuring precipitation totals in precise locations within the U.S. and Canada. 
- Unlike typical weather apps, it provides accurate, detailed data on how much rain or moisture has fallen, available by city, zip code, or exact address for the last 12, 24, or 48 hours.
- The base app is free and ad-free, with a premium subscription available for extra features; it requires only email sign-in and ensures data privacy.

items.title: WhatsApp banned on Capitol Hill; How to secure your Meta messaging
items.summary:
- The U.S. House of Representatives banned WhatsApp on government phones, citing high risks from lack of transparency, unencrypted backups, and security gaps despite its end-to-end encryption.  
- WhatsApp collects extensive metadata sent to Meta, which is not fully disclosed, contributing to privacy concerns; user backups to cloud services are not end-to-end encrypted by default.  
- To improve WhatsApp security, enable end-to-end encrypted backups, lock the app with biometrics, and activate two-step verification; alternatives suggested include iMessage, Signal, Wickr, and Microsoft Teams.

items.title: Why the ‘Tiny Chef’ cancellation broke the internet’s heart
items.author: Eve Upton-Clark
items.summary:
- The stop-motion animated show *The Tiny Chef Show* was unexpectedly canceled by Nickelodeon, deeply affecting fans and the show's creators.  
- A viral video showing Tiny Chef, the show's character, reacting emotionally to the cancellation resonated widely, sparking online support and calls for crowdfunding to continue the series.  
- The series was notable for its authentic storytelling, celebrity announcements, and tiny culinary creations, with fans lamenting the loss and criticizing the network's decision.

items.title: Bumble is stumbling. Tinder is flagging. But this go-to gay dating app is thriving
items.summary: - *Bumble* is facing declining revenue, user growth, and recently laid off 30% of its staff, while *Grindr* is experiencing strong growth in both users and revenue, driven by innovative features. - Grindr CEO George Arison emphasizes product-led innovation, with features like Albums and Right Now increasing engagement, contrasting with Bumble's slower feature rollout. - Both apps are expanding into friendship and alternate markets, but Grindr's integrated approach and new ventures, including telemedicine, position it to become more than just a dating app.

items.title: This AI-powered social app aims to end loneliness—by ‘engineering chance’
items.summary:
- The social platform *222* uses an AI-driven algorithm to facilitate *chance encounters* and combat social isolation without swiping or user choice.  
- Originating from a personality-based research project, 222 matches users to curated social events to deepen relationships and connect people to their cities.  
- Launched in several US cities and expanding internationally, 222 charges users a curation fee and gathers feedback to improve matching, aiming for lasting social infrastructure.

items.title: Why Apple is revamping its App Store terms in the European Union
items.summary:
- Apple has revised its App Store policies in the *EU* to avoid escalating fines under the Digital Markets Act following a €500 million penalty for restricting developers from directing users to cheaper outside options.
- The new terms allow developers to guide users to alternative payment methods and introduce a two-tier fee system for those opting for external payments.
- The European Commission will review these changes for compliance, while Apple plans to appeal the decision, highlighting ongoing tensions over *big tech* regulation.

items.title: Gen Alpha slang baffles parents—and AI
Gen Alpha Slang Baffles Parents—and AI
items.summary: - A study by Gen Alpha students reveals that top AI models and parents struggle to understand rapidly evolving slang used by Gen Alpha (born 2010–2024). - AI notably fails to detect nuanced contexts like **masked harassment**, raising safety concerns. - Gen Alpha’s language shifts quickly, highlighting a widening comprehension gap impacting online safety and moderation.

items.title: Has AI already rotted my brain?
items.summary:
- A recent MIT study reveals that relying on AI like ChatGPT for tasks such as essay writing can make thinking 'too easy,' potentially eroding critical thinking and motivation for independent problem-solving.
- The author compares AI to an e-bike for the mind, acknowledging the risks of overdependence but believing AI can be embraced to enhance productivity and creativity rather than diminish mental acuity.
- The article warns of a cultural shift toward using AI for shortcuts, citing a startup promoting cheating with AI, underscoring the challenge of maintaining genuine cognitive engagement in an AI-rich world.

items.title: Aurora Hits Self-Driving Trucking Milestone Amid Challenges
items.summary:
- In May, Aurora completed a major milestone by delivering cargo on public roads with fully driverless semitrailer trucks between Dallas and Houston, after eight years of development.  
- The achievement came after delaying the launch by six months to finalize their *safety case* testing and self-certification, underscoring the complexity of autonomous trucking.  
- Despite this success, safety operators were reinstated in the trucks two weeks later, highlighting ongoing *challenges* in deploying fully autonomous commercial trucking at scale.

items.title: Why Gen Z is ditching popular emojis for unexpected alternatives
items.author: Eve Upton-Clark
items.summary:
- Gen Z is replacing mainstream emojis like the broken heart with more *creative* and *unexpected* alternatives such as the wilted rose emoji.  
- Viral TikTok trends promote less commonly used emojis, like the aerial tramway, to gain new cultural meanings and popularity.  
- This emoji swapping reflects *internet culture's* ironic and chaotic meme dynamics, with younger users redefining emoji usage beyond traditional expressions.

items.title: Wall Street Reacts to Zohran Mamdani's NYC Mayoral Primary Win
items.summary: - Zohran Mamdani's victory in the NYC Democratic mayoral primary sparked a Wall Street meltdown, with finance leaders like Dan Loeb coining the term **'hot commie summer'** to describe the political shift. - Billionaires who supported Andrew Cuomo expressed frustration as Mamdani's win threatens potential **tax hikes and tighter regulations** feared by Wall Street. - Social media users joked about wealthy New Yorkers moving to Miami and finance bros adapting to the new political landscape, highlighting the growing divide between finance interests and Mamdani's platform.

items.title: Tesla’s Robotaxi Test Launch in Austin Faces Safety Concerns
items.summary: - Tesla’s robotaxi pilot in Austin encountered multiple *driving errors* such as wrong-lane entry, sudden braking, and unsafe drop-offs, raising safety questions. - Videos from test riders revealed issues including driving in oncoming lanes and abrupt stopping, despite human safety monitors in the cars. - Experts and officials express concern, noting this early phase shows *significant challenges* and emphasizing collaboration to improve safety before wider rollout.

items.title: Generative AI is finding fertile soil in the healthcare industry
items.summary:
- *Generative AI*, like ChatGPT, is increasingly used in healthcare for diagnosis assistance, clinical documentation, and reducing physician burnout, evidenced by tools such as AI scribes deployed at the Cleveland Clinic.  
- Innovative platforms like *OpenEvidence* provide doctors with AI-powered, evidence-based clinical decision support by summarizing trusted medical literature, rapidly gaining adoption among U.S. physicians.  
- Emotionally intelligent AI models from companies like *Hume AI* are emerging in eldercare and mental health, providing companionship, therapy support, and automated session note-taking, enhancing patient and caregiver experiences.

items.title: Scammers Use AI and TikTok to Fake Animal Shelter Videos
items.author: Eve Upton-Clark
items.summary:
- Scammers are repurposing videos of elderly TikTok users to fake emotional appeals for animal shelters, tricking viewers into donating or buying products under false pretenses.
- Victims like George Tsaftarides and Charles Ray have discovered their TikTok content stolen and manipulated, with difficulty getting fraudulent videos removed despite TikTok's policies.
- The FBI reports a $12.5 billion loss to cybercrime in 2024, with AI-generated scams increasing; TikTok users are now raising awareness about these common fraudulent tactics.

items.title: Why Lyft is convening its drivers to plan the future of robotaxis
items.summary:
- *Lyft* is launching the Driver Autonomous Forum to involve drivers directly in planning the *transition to autonomous vehicle (AV)* integration, aiming for a *hybrid* model of human and robotaxi rideshares.
- Drivers fear *loss of income and independence* due to robotaxi competition, reflecting concerns over decreased earnings in markets saturated with AVs like Phoenix and LA.
- While AVs may *expand the rideshare market*, experts note that many drivers treat rideshare as side income, so robotaxis may reduce supplemental earnings rather than primary jobs.

items.title: Stephen Miller has a hefty financial stake in a key ICE contractor
items.summary:
- Stephen Miller, a key architect of aggressive immigration enforcement policies, holds a significant investment in Palantir, a major contractor for ICE and DHS.  
- Ethics experts raise concerns about conflict of interest due to Miller's dual role influencing immigration enforcement policies and financially benefiting from Palantir's government contracts.  
- Despite ethical concerns, Palantir's stock surged after Miller's investment was made public; the company plays a crucial role in monitoring and enforcing immigration cases under current policy frameworks.

items.title: Future Mirror: AI Art Meets Handmade Prototypes
items.summary:
- Danish artist Andreas Refsgaard blends generative *AI* with *handcrafted prototypes* to envision futuristic artifacts via the *Future Mirror* project.
- The project invites students to build recycled material models that are fed into *Stable Diffusion*, generating imaginative visualizations of yet-to-exist worlds.
- This approach highlights a new creative process, combining children’s *imagination* with AI to produce unique, unexpected art, questioning the future role of artists.

items.title: How the Internet of Things impacts everyone’s privacy
BeReal is back. Can it stick around this time?
items.author: Eve Upton-Clark
items.summary:
- BeReal, the photo-sharing app famous for its *authentic, real-time* photo prompts, surged in 2022 but saw downloads and usage sharply decline by 2023, leading to its sale to gaming firm Voodoo for €500 million.
- The company plans a *comeback* with new features like “Nearby” and targeted marketing efforts, focusing on Gen Z users disillusioned with traditional social media filters and engagement pressures.
- Despite changes, BeReal’s original success was tied to a *unique cultural moment* that fostered genuine connection, and it remains uncertain if it can regain that lightning in a bottle effect.

items.title: Bipartisan bill aims to ban Chinese AI from federal agencies
items.summary:
- A bipartisan group of U.S. lawmakers introduced the *No Adversarial AI Act* to ban Chinese AI systems from federal agencies, citing AI as central in the new Cold War with China.  
- Experts warn China is rapidly closing the AI performance gap, emphasizing the need for the U.S. to maintain strict export controls on high-tech chips to limit China's AI capabilities.  
- The competition is framed as a race between *democratic* versus *authoritarian* AI, with global political and security implications hinging on who leads in AI technology.

items.title: U.S. strikes on Iran’s nuclear program have unleashed cyberattacks on American banks and the oil industry
Why everyone on social media is ‘monitoring the situation’
Genesys launches agentic AI to transform customer service
items.summary:
- Tony Bates, CEO of Genesys since 2019, is driving the company into the era of *agentic AI*.
- Genesys Cloud AI Studio enables businesses to build and scale *autonomous AI agents* for customer service without coding.
- These AI agents can operate across departments and workflows, making interactions *less robotic* and more efficient.

items.title: The AI baby boom is here. But can ChatGPT really raise a child?
items.summary: - *Many new parents*, including OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, are *relying on ChatGPT* and AI tools for parenting advice and childcare support. - Specialized AI apps and gadgets, such as AI doulas and smart baby monitors, are expanding AI's role *at every stage of parenting*. - Experts warn of *information overload* leading to reduced parental confidence, emphasizing that *human judgment and community support* are essential beyond chatbot advice.

items.title: Navan's AI Platform Tackles Zero-Hallucinations in Travel Automation
items.summary:
- Navan launched Cognition, an AI workforce platform, to eliminate critical hallucinations in travel booking and expense management.
- The system uses specialized AI agents supervised by AI 'managers' to ensure *accuracy* and *reliability*, inspired by human neural networks and organizational structures.
- With zero critical hallucinations reported, Navan plans to scale Cognition and offer it to other companies, innovating despite being smaller than AI giants.

items.title: I’ve become an AI vibecoding convert
Top 10 Emerging Technologies of 2025 by WEF
items.author: Chris Morris
items.summary:
- The World Economic Forum highlights *10 emerging technologies* expected to influence global challenges by 2025.
- Key innovations include *advanced nuclear tech* for cleaner energy, *structural battery composites* for lighter vehicles, and *generative watermarking* to verify AI content.
- Other notable technologies are *green nitrogen*, *nanozymes*, and *engineered living therapeutics*, promising sustainable solutions in energy, environment, and healthcare.

items.title: Anthropic’s AI copyright ‘win’ is more complicated than it looks
items.summary: - *Anthropic* won a key fair use ruling allowing AI training on copyrighted materials, with the judge calling the training ‘exceedingly transformative.’  - However, the ruling is *not a total victory*, as allegations of piracy sourcing from Anthropic could lead to substantial liabilities in a forthcoming trial. - Experts emphasize this is *only an initial step*; appeals and jurisdictional limits mean the long-term impact on *AI copyright law remains uncertain.*

items.title: How Roblox handles millions of players on viral games like ‘Grow a Garden’
items.summary: - Roblox handled a *peak of 30.6 million concurrent players*, with the viral game *Grow a Garden* reaching 21.6 million players simultaneously. - Its infrastructure supports *real-time updates* by third-party developers and extensive traffic load through 24 global edge data centers and a private global network. - Weekly capacity planning, chaos testing, and on-call engineering (including executives) ensure *performance and resilience* during viral surges and weekends.

items.title: Warp's agentic development environment revolutionizes AI coding workflows
items.summary:
- Warp, renowned for its AI-powered terminal, launches an *agentic development environment* that integrates AI agents into developer workflows.
- The tool blends terminal-style interaction, AI supervision controls, and collaborative features, enabling prompt-based coding and deployment with human oversight.
- This all-in-one environment offers advanced management of AI code generation, giving Warp a competitive edge over existing AI coding tools.

items.title: Nonstop news alerts are driving people to disable their phone notifications
items.summary: - Mobile phone users receive *up to 50 news alerts daily*, causing widespread *alert fatigue*. - Nearly *43% of users disable notifications* due to notification overload. - Many avoid news alerts to reduce *emotional distress* and manage information overload.

items.title: Meet the 4 a.m. club, TikTok’s mystical election night movement
items.author: Eve Upton-Clark
items.summary:
- The *4 a.m. club* is a TikTok community claiming a shared mystical experience at 4 a.m. on November 6, 2024, feeling spiritually "activated" during the U.S. election night.
- Members report sensing an alternate timeline where Kamala Harris won, despite official results favoring Donald Trump.
- Founded organically by psychic Gia Prism, the club blends *spiritual healing* with *political activism* and remains hopeful for future changes.

items.title: Meet Delphi, the AI startup that lets experts turn themselves into chatbots
items.summary: - **Delphi** is an AI startup creating 'digital minds,' chatbots trained on a specific expert's own content to reflect their unique knowledge and style. - It enables creators with existing followings to engage audiences via text or voice chat, helping scale advice and monetize interactions. - The startup raised $16 million Series A led by Sequoia Capital to expand features and improve personalized AI experiences.

items.title: The rise of the personal AI advisers
The rise of the personal AI advisers
items.summary: - A viral Reddit story showed ChatGPT solving a five-year medical mystery in seconds, highlighting AI's growing role as a *life adviser* especially for Gen Z and millennials.  - Younger generations prefer AI chatbots over traditional search engines for *personalized*, conversational advice on health, career, and finances. - The future envisions *always-on, tailored AI agents* acting as expert proxies that offer context-aware, continuous guidance, potentially reshaping information seeking and decision-making.

items.title: Raindrop.io: A Free and Powerful Pocket Replacement
items.summary:
- **Raindrop.io** is an *all-in-one bookmark manager* perfect for saving and organizing webpages, serving as a strong, free alternative to Pocket.
- It offers *beautiful, modern interfaces* across platforms including browser extensions, mobile, desktop apps, and a web interface.
- Basic features are *free and ad-free* with unlimited bookmarks, while a $3/month Pro plan adds advanced tools like full-text search and permanent archiving.

items.title: Bilt: Startup Rewarding Rent Payments with Points
items.summary:
- *Bilt Rewards* offers points on rent payments, launching a novel *credit card* targeting renters, a huge untapped market.
- The startup boasts nearly *5 million members* and partnerships with *70% of top U.S. multifamily property owners*.
- Founder Ankur Jain pivots from credit rewards to creating a *tenant loyalty and payment platform*, reshaping rent payment methods.

items.title: Robinhood’s comeback story: from GameStop scandal to record profits
items.summary: - Robinhood faced intense scrutiny after the 2021 GameStop controversy. - In response, it rebuilt trust and launched *powerful new tools.* - These efforts led to its *strongest financial performance ever* in the following year.
